sentences.english: The bus stopped suddenly, this causing the delay.
sentences.chinese: 汽車突然停開，造成耽擱。

sentences.english: Finally, we found no association between the incidence of AVN and operation delay.
sentences.chinese: 最後我們沒有發現手術耽擱和缺血性壞死之間的關係。

sentences.english: The bad weather detained the travellers for several hours.
sentences.chinese: 惡劣的天氣耽擱了旅行者幾個小時。

sentences.english: Are you willing to stop procrastinating and start doing?
sentences.chinese: 你想要不再耽擱時間並開始做事嗎？

sentences.english: Keep checking the board to see if his flight has been delayed.
sentences.chinese: 持續查看告示板，看看他的班機是否耽擱了。

sentences.english: I wonder why he tarried so long.
sentences.chinese: 我不明白他爲什麼耽擱那麼久。

sentences.english: I must have this cloth woven for me without delay.
sentences.chinese: 我要他們不耽擱地爲我織出這樣的布。

sentences.english: What else can detain him at Norland?
sentences.chinese: 還有什麼事情能把他耽擱在諾蘭莊園呢？

sentences.english: For in just a very little while, “He who is coming will come and will not delay.” Hebrews 10:36-37 (NIV)
sentences.chinese: 只消一小會兒，“將會到來的不會耽擱。”

sentences.english: "I got held up in traffic, " Kugelmass said.
sentences.chinese: “我被堵車給耽擱了，”庫馬思說道。

sentences.english: We are experiencing a slight delay becase of the weather.
sentences.chinese: 因爲天氣的關係，我們會稍稍耽擱一下。

sentences.english: Ponce was not a man to wast time in any undertaking.
sentences.chinese: 龐塞是位做任何事情都不耽擱時間的人。

sentences.english: This delay facilitated the Spanish victory in the Battle of Bailen in July.
sentences.chinese: 這耽擱有助西班牙軍隊在七月的拜倫戰役中取勝。

sentences.english: So come quickly, Livesey, do not lose an hour!
sentences.chinese: 李甫西，快來吧，一鐘頭也不要耽擱。

sentences.english: The taxi was delayed in the rush - hour traffic .
sentences.chinese: 出租車在交通高峯時間被耽擱了。

definition: to change one's mind/to go back on one's word
to submit to humiliation (idiom); to suffer in silence/to swallow one's anger/to grin and bear it
the gains do not make up for the losses (idiom)
to follow the track of an overturned cart/to repeat a disastrous policy
to have one's spirits dampened/to feel disappointed
to brace oneself to do sth/to put a bold face on it/to summon up courage/to force oneself to
lit. beat the grass to scare the snake (idiom)/fig. to inadvertently alert an enemy/to punish sb as a warning to others
